lib
Class DrawableImage<T>

java.lang.Object
  lib.DrawableImage<T>
All Implemented Interfaces:
Drawable, StackIterator<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
chip, StockArt
public class DrawableImage<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements Drawable, StackIterator<T>

DrawableImage is an extension on Image, with support for loading, masking, scaling and displaying the images. See class StockArt for a collection of useful images.

Most of the "chip" classes are subclasses of stockart.

The general characteristics of DrawableImage is that they are immutable, scalable images that are used by the program. Generally, one copy of the image is loaded into a static variable at initialization time, and used throughout the rest of the program. Machinery in the canvas creates scaled copies and takes care of drawing the image with an appropriate size. The canvas also has an "image substitution" mechanism so alternate chipsets can be used without changing the actual contents of the board.

Author:
ddyer

Field Detail

file

public java.lang.String file
the file from which this image was loaded

scale

public double[] scale
An array of 3 elements, x offset, y offset and scale factor.
These parameters are used to normalize the location and size of the image relative to its center. This array is normally set up during construction and not changed.

image

public java.awt.Image image
the underlying image for this StockArt. Normally this is set by a static initializer, but sometimes it's useful to delay loading. This probably shouldn't be used to implement changeable images.

getScale

public double[] getScale()
get the scale factor array for this image, which is the normal x,y,scale to display the image. The neutral values would be {0.5,0.5,1.0}

These scale factors are normally hand-tuned so the default size and positioning of the artwork is as desired - the alternative to using these scale factors is to actually edit the image with photoshop.

Note that if you stay within the system, you'll never need to see or use these scale factors, they're just an internal detail you tune so the images look right.

Returns:
an array double[3]

Parameters:
canvas - an exCanvas or null

drawChipFancyText

public void drawChipFancyText(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                              exCanvas canvas,
                              int SQUARESIZE,
                              int cx,
                              int cy,
                              java.lang.String label,
                              boolean artCenter)
draw the image (or it's alternate) and a text string to label it. The string is drawn centered according to the x,y offset. The image is drawn centered at the x,y specified, and scaled to fill the specified square size, as adjusted by the image's internal offset and scale factors.

Parameters:
gc - a graphics or null
canvas - the canvas to draw on
SQUARESIZE -
cx -
cy -
label - the string label, or null
artCenter - if true, draw text at teh artwork center rather than the image center.
See Also:
drawImage

drawChipImage

public void drawChipImage(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                          exCanvas canvas,
                          int cx,
                          int cy,
                          double[] pscale,
                          int SQUARESIZE,
                          double xscale,
                          double jitter,
                          java.lang.String label,
                          boolean artcenter)
this is the lowest level overridable method, which actually passes to the canvas for drawing. Stock art which constructs its image in complex ways can override this method. The standard definition of this method is canvas.drawImage(gc, getImage(), pscale,cx, cy, SQUARESIZE, xscale,yscale,label,artcenter);

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        CellId rackLocation,
                        int squareWidth,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel)
draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity. If the highlight is hit, the width is increased by 1/3 to give a visual "pop" to indicate the hit.

Parameters:
gc - // the graphics to draw with
drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing
highlight - // the mouse point, or null. Receives hit information
rackLocation - // the cellId to use for this if hit
squareWidth - // the overall scale of the object
e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        CellId rackLocation,
                        int squareWidth,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel,
                        double sscale,
                        double expansion)
draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity. If the highlight is hit, the width is multiplied by "expansion" to give a visual "pop" to indicate the hit.

Parameters:
gc - // the graphics to draw with
drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing
highlight - // the mouse point, or null. Receives hit information
rackLocation - // the cellId to use for this if hit
squareWidth - // the overall scale of the object
e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
sscale - // sensitive area scale factor, default 0.66
expansion - // size expansion factor
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

drawChip

public boolean drawChip(java.awt.Graphics gc,
                        exCanvas drawOn,
                        HitPoint highlight,
                        CellId rackLocation,
                        int squareWidth,
                        double scale,
                        int e_x,
                        int e_y,
                        java.lang.String thislabel)
draw a chip and test for mouse sensitivity. If the highlight is hit, the width is increased by 1/3 to give a visual "pop" to indicate the hit.

Parameters:
gc - // the graphics to draw with
drawOn - // the canvas to do the drawing
highlight - // the mouse point, or null. Receives hit information
rackLocation - // the rack code for this location
squareWidth - // the overall scale of the object
scale - // the percentage scale of the x axis (used to stretch or squish)
e_x - // the center of the object
e_y - // the center y of the object
thislabel - // label to print on top
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

findChipHighlight

public boolean findChipHighlight(CellId rackLocation,
                                 HitPoint highlight,
                                 DrawableImage<T> piece,
                                 int squareWidth,
                                 int squareHeight,
                                 int x,
                                 int y)
test the highlight point for a hit on this piece, as adjusted by the image aspect ratio, the scale, and offsets for this chip. If a hit is declared, registerChipHit(lib.CellId, lib.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) is called

Parameters:
racklocation - the CellId of the object being tested
highlight - the current pointer location
piece - null or the item used to scale width and height
squareWidth - the width of the space to fit into
squareHeight - the height of the space to fit into
x - the center x to draw
y - the center y to draw
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

                                           int width,
                                           int x,
                                           int y)
get the rectangle containing this chip, as drawn with the specified width location. This takes into account the x,y,size scale of the chip and the actual aspect ratio of the chip.

y -
Returns:
the containing rectangle

findChipHighlight

public boolean findChipHighlight(CellId rackLocation,
                                 HitPoint highlight,
                                 int e_x,
                                 int e_y,
                                 int squareWidth,
                                 int squareHeight)
test the highlight point for a hit on this piece, as adjusted by the image aspect ratio, the scale, and offsets for this chip. If a hit is declared, registerChipHit(lib.CellId, lib.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) is called

Parameters:
highlight - the current pointer location
squareWidth - the width of the space to fit into
squareHeight - the height of the space to fit into
racklocation - the CellId of the object being tested
x - the center x to draw
y - the center y to draw
Returns:
true if this chip is hit

findChipHighlight

public boolean findChipHighlight(CellId rackLocation,
                                 HitPoint highlight,
                                 int e_x,
                                 int e_y,
                                 int squareWidth,
                                 int squareHeight,
                                 double sscale)
do highlight detection for drawChip(java.awt.Graphics, online.common.exCanvas, int, int, int, java.lang.String) and drawStack This uses pointInsideCell(lib.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) to determine if the point is inside, and calls registerChipHit(lib.CellId, lib.HitPoint, int, int, int, int) to mark the hit in the highlight object.

Parameters:
highlight -
e_x -
e_y -
squareWidth -
Returns:
true if this is the first hit

pointInsideCell

public boolean pointInsideCell(HitPoint pt,
                               int x,
                               int y,
                               int SQW,
                               int SQH)
this method is made visible so you can tweak the radius that constitutes a hit. Note that the target is a 2/3 smaller square, not a circle.

Parameters:
pt - the mouse location
x - x position of the chip
y - y position of the chip
SQW - square cell width of the chip
SQH - is the cell height of the chip
Returns:
true of point is inside the square centered at x,y
See Also:
drawChipHighlight, drawChip, drawStack

pointInsideCell

public boolean pointInsideCell(HitPoint pt,
                               int x,
                               int y,
                               int SQW,
                               int SQH,
                               double sscale)
this method is made visible so you can tweak the radius that constitutes a hit. Note that the target is a smaller square, not a circle.

Parameters:
pt - the mouse location
x - x position of the chip
y - y position of the chip
SQW - square cell width of the chip
SQH - is the cell height of the chip
sscale - the scale applied to width and height
Returns:
true of point is inside the square centered at x,y
See Also:
drawChipHighlight, drawChip, drawStack

Parameters:

Returns:

allChips - the chips ready to be loaded
